availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition
Early Access

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, Beriah Magoffin: Governor's Official Correspondence File, Petitions for Pardons and Remissions, 1859-1862

body.p: Mr. Nelson Volentine was fined at the April Term of the Knox circuit court for keeping a Tipling Huse (fine $60)

The circumstances are these- John J. Jones. Had lisence to keep a Tavern He got Volentine to keep His Bar or rather sold Him the Bar privledges. Jones represented to Volentine that His time would have been Expire at the July August county court, When in fact it was out at the June County court Volentine sold liquor during the interval, believing that the lisence was not out until August at the August Court the License were renewed. He did not intend to violate Law. believe He had a right to sell. Times are Hard no money in the county. Please remit

Knox Cir. Ct
$60. } Tipling
N. Volentine
Remission Issd
May 9. 1861
